message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of temper outbursts, irritability, and physical aggression without affecting academic performance suggest a diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. Pediatric bipolar disorder usually involves mood swings, and Conduct disorder involves violating rules and the rights of others. Intermittent explosive disorder involves recurrent aggressive behavior, but it usually develops after 18 years of age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. The key features are chronic irritability and recurrent temper outbursts that are severe, developmental inappropriate and inconsistent with situation. The outbursts must occur three or more times a week for at least one year. Pediatric bipolar disorder may also have symptoms of irritability and temper outbursts, but it requires a history of manic or hypomanic episodes. Conduct disorder requires a persistent pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others and societal norms. Intermittent explosive disorder refers to recurrent outbursts of aggression that are out of proportion with the situation, and there is usually a sense of relief after the outburst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of temper outbursts and irritability suggest disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD). Conduct disorder (CD) is characterized by aggression towards other people and animals and violation of social norms. Pediatric bipolar disorder (BD) is characterized by manic and depressive episodes, which are not present in this case. Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) is characterized by verbal or physical outbursts of anger, which are not limited to temper tantrums and occur more frequently in adults than children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, which is characterized by frequent temperamental outbursts and persistent irritability. Pediatric bipolar disorder and intermittent explosive disorder are less likely explanations as they do not fully match the symptoms described. Conduct disorder involves aggression directed towards other people, but it does not involve the same frequency of temper outbursts or irritability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms match those of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, which is characterized by severe and recurrent temper tantrums that are grossly out of proportion in intensity or duration to the situation or provocation. Conduct disorder involves violation of the rights of others, but this child’s grades remain unaffected. Intermittent explosive disorder involves discrete episodes of failure to resist aggressive impulses, which is not the case in this scenario. Pediatric bipolar disorder involves periods of both elevated and depressive moods, which are not described in the scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of temper outbursts and irritability, as well as the fact that the child is uncooperative during the mental status examination, suggest Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD), which is characterized by severe and recurrent temper outbursts and a persistent irritable or angry mood. Pediatric bipolar disorder and intermittent explosive disorder have similar symptoms but do not fit the duration and frequency criteria for DMDD. Conduct disorder is also a possibility, but it is more commonly associated with aggressive behaviors outside of the home setting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the frequency and duration of temper outbursts, suggest Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. Conduct disorder is characterized by violating the rights of others and societal norms, which is not a prominent feature in this case. Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by sudden, aggressive outbursts, but it typically occurs in adults, not children. Pediatric bipolar disorder involves mood swings between highs and lows, which is not evident in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of temper outbursts and irritability suggest disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, which is characterized by chronic, severe irritability and frequent, severe temper outbursts disproportionate to the situation. Conduct disorder involves violation of rules and rights of others, but the symptoms are not specific to this disorder. Pediatric bipolar disorder and intermittent explosive disorder could also present with irritability and temper outbursts, but the onset at age 6 and a half is more consistent with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of temper outbursts, irritability, and restlessness are consistent with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, which is a relatively new diagnosis added to the DSM-5. Conduct disorder and intermittent explosive disorder are also possible but do not fully capture the presentation. Pediatric bipolar disorder would require a longer history of symptoms and is less likely given the age of onset.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of irritability and temper outbursts, even between outbursts, suggest disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. Conduct disorder involves more serious aggressive behavior, and pediatric bipolar disorder typically involves mood swings and elevated moods. Intermittent explosive disorder involves sudden, impulsive, and aggressive outbursts that are not typically premeditated or related to a specific trigger.
